content: The "Commonsense Reporting and Verification Act of 2015" includes provisions for a prospective reporting system, protection of dependent privacy, electronic statements, GAO studies, and an eligibility verification process for ACA subsidies. The Act may be cited as the "Commonsense Reporting and Verification Act of 2015". The "Commonsense Reporting and Verification Act of 2015" aims to minimize compliance burdens under the Affordable Care Act while protecting individual privacy. It includes provisions for a prospective reporting system and eligibility verification for ACA subsidies. The Act mandates the implementation of a voluntary prospective reporting system by the Secretary of the Treasury within 180 days of enactment. Employers can use this system for plan years starting after December 31, 2015. The system must meet specific requirements and be maintained by the Secretary of the Treasury. The system, established by the Secretary of the Treasury, must be available for employers to use for plan years starting after December 31, 2015. It includes a process for employers to voluntarily report their information. Employers can voluntarily report their information, including the employer's name, identification number, certification of offering coverage to full-time employees, dependents, and spouses. Section 5000A(f) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 requires employers to offer coverage to full-time employees, dependents, spouses, and part-time employees. The coverage must also meet the minimum value requirement specified in section 36B(c)(2)(C)(ii) of the Code. Employers must offer coverage to full-time employees, dependents, spouses, and part-time employees. The coverage must meet minimum value requirements and affordability safe harbors. Employers must report whether the coverage offered to full-time employees meets affordability safe harbors, availability to employees, and any waiting periods, 60 days before the coverage starts. Employers must report the availability of coverage to full-time employees, including any waiting periods, 60 days before the open enrollment period. This information must be securely accessible to Exchanges, the Federal Marketplace Data Services Hub, and the IRS. The open enrollment period under the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act allows Exchanges, the Federal Marketplace Data Services Hub, and the IRS to securely access necessary information for eligibility determinations. The process includes obtaining additional information from employers to determine eligibility for premium tax credits and cost-sharing subsidies under the Affordable Care Act. The process includes obtaining necessary information from employers to verify eligibility for advance payment and cost-sharing subsidies under the Affordable Care Act, allowing for timely updates to the Federal Marketplace Data Services Hub. The system allows employers to verify eligibility for advance payment and cost-sharing subsidies under the Affordable Care Act, provide updates to the Federal Marketplace Data Services Hub, and report any changes in coverage for participating employees. The system created allows employers to report any cancellation of coverage or significant changes in availability for participating employees, exempting them from certain reporting requirements under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Employers meeting certain plan year end requirements are considered to have satisfied return and statement furnishing requirements under section 6056 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Employers meeting plan year end requirements are considered to have satisfied return and statement furnishing requirements under section 6056 of the Internal Revenue Code if they provide the necessary information to the IRS and employees who have enrolled in a qualified health plan. Employees who have enrolled in a qualified health plan through the Exchange or are eligible for premium tax credits or cost-sharing subsidies under the Affordable Care Act are considered to have satisfied requirements under the Internal Revenue Code. Employees who have enrolled in a qualified health plan through the Exchange or are eligible for premium tax credits or cost-sharing subsidies under the Affordable Care Act can use third parties for filing without affecting their employer's liability under the Internal Revenue Code. Employers can use third parties for filing without affecting their liability under the Internal Revenue Code. Exchanges must notify employers when an employee or dependent enrolls in a qualified health plan. SEC. 4. PROTECTION OF DEPENDENT PRIVACY. Section 6055(b) of the Internal Revenue Code is amended to allow for the use of an individual's name and date of birth in place of their TIN if not collected before January 1, 2014. This amendment applies to protect dependent privacy. The amendment allows for using an individual's name and date of birth instead of their TIN if not collected, effective for returns due after 60 days from the enactment of the Act. SEC. 5. ELECTRONIC STATEMENTS. Section 6056(c) of the Internal Revenue Code is amended to allow individuals to receive statements electronically if they have previously consented to it with their employer. Refusal in writing can override this consent. Section 6055(c) of the Internal Revenue Code now allows individuals to receive health insurance coverage statements electronically if they have consented with their employer. Refusal in writing can override this consent. The Internal Revenue Code allows electronic delivery of health insurance coverage statements if individuals have previously consented to receive private health information electronically. Refusal in writing can override this consent. The amendments made by this section apply to statements due after December 31, 2015, allowing electronic delivery of health insurance coverage statements if individuals have previously consented to receive private health information electronically. The amendments allow electronic delivery of health insurance coverage statements if individuals have consented to receive private health information electronically. GAO studies. The Comptroller General of the United States will conduct a study evaluating employer notification by Exchanges under the Affordable Care Act regarding full-time employees eligible for advance payment of premium tax credits. The study will evaluate employer notification by Exchanges under the Affordable Care Act regarding full-time employees eligible for advance payment of premium tax credits. It will include details on data elements and the notification process. The study will assess employer notification by Exchanges under the Affordable Care Act for full-time employees eligible for premium tax credits, including data elements and notification process details. The study will evaluate employer notification by Exchanges under the Affordable Care Act for full-time employees eligible for premium tax credits, focusing on the process details such as formal notice and comment period, sufficiency of information provided to employers, total number of notifications sent, and timeline of notifications. The study will assess employer notification by Exchanges under the Affordable Care Act for full-time employees eligible for premium tax credits, including details on the notification process, differences between Federal and State-Based Marketplaces, challenges faced, and recommendations. The study will evaluate employer notification processes under the Affordable Care Act for full-time employees eligible for premium tax credits, focusing on differences between Federal and State-Based Marketplaces, challenges faced, and recommendations. It will also examine whether the Secretary of Health and Human Services has established a separate appeals process for employers to challenge eligibility determinations. The Comptroller General will report on employer notification processes under the Affordable Care Act for full-time employees eligible for premium tax credits, including the establishment of a separate appeals process for employers to challenge eligibility determinations. The Comptroller General will submit a report on employer notification processes under the Affordable Care Act for full-time employees eligible for premium tax credits, including a study of a prospective reporting system. The Comptroller General will conduct a study evaluating the functionality of the prospective reporting system established under section 3, including the accuracy of information collected and the number of employers participating. States will conduct a study to evaluate the prospective reporting system established under section 3 from January 1, 2017, to December 31, 2017. The study will assess the accuracy of information collected, the number of employers reporting, and any implementation challenges. The Comptroller General must submit a report to specific Senate and House committees by July 1, 2018. The Comptroller General will submit a report to Senate and House committees by July 1, 2018, on the results of a study evaluating the reporting system established under section 3. The report will include information on the accuracy of data collected, number of employers reporting, and any implementation challenges. SEC. 7. ELIGIBILITY VERIFICATION PROCESS FOR ACA SUBSIDIES. A marketplace can automatically reenroll an individual in a qualified health plan annually, as long as eligibility for subsidies is redetermined and changes in premiums and the Federal poverty level are considered. The marketplace can reenroll individuals annually in a qualified health plan, considering changes in premiums, Federal poverty level, and income data for subsidy eligibility. If the marketplace doesn't follow the specified processes, automatic reenrollment with subsidies is not allowed. The marketplace may not automatically reenroll individuals into a qualified health plan with subsidies if current income information is not provided, as per the specified processes. The marketplace requires individuals to provide current income information to redetermine eligibility for subsidies on a qualified health plan. This aligns with guidance from the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services for annual eligibility redeterminations and reenrollments. The Secretary will follow guidance on annual eligibility redeterminations and reenrollments for marketplace coverage, ensuring comprehensive rules for automatic reenrollment of eligible individuals. The Secretary will issue guidance on reenrollments for coverage and tax credits, ensuring comprehensive rules for automatic reenrollment of eligible individuals. This guidance will require enrollees to maintain authorization for disclosure of information verifying eligibility for tax credits or cost-sharing reductions. The marketplace must maintain authorization for disclosure of information to verify eligibility for tax credits or cost-sharing reductions, request updated income information annually, and provide notices on redeterminations and reenrollments to enrollees. The marketplace annually requests updated income information to verify eligibility and provides notices on redeterminations and reenrollments to enrollees. The term "marketplace" refers to State Based Exchanges and the Federally Facilitated Exchange established under the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act.
